The stations expressed great concern with the need to up-grade pro¬
duction practices in the various stations; to develop some plan of
exchanging personnel between stations for short periods as part of
this up-grading development; and to study and apply sound management
techniques to personnel recruiting and training.
4. One part of the proposed television development seminar -- but one
receiving special emphasis from the stations -- would deal with act¬
ivation of new stations and the special need for training personnel
to staff the new stations.
5. The stations urged the NAEB staff to give every possible assistance
to the FCC Broadcast Bureau in finding a properly qualified person to
fill the position being created as head of the Education Division. It
was suggested that a careful review of the NAEB membership be made by
a committee as the first step in this search.
6. The stations requested, and the Television Board approves a request
that NAEB institute an application to the FCC for a rule-making pro¬
cedure to amend the rules relating to Translator operation to permit
original programming by non-commercial educational licensees on these
assignments.
7. The stations hope that the up-coming study of NAEB membership
qualifications will include information on the availability of people
within television stations who are available for emergency loan to
stations needing help in various phases of their operation.
Loren B -Stone, Chairman
NAEB Television Board
